acquaintance: a person that you have met but do not know well
addition: the process of adding numbers or amounts together
aisle: a long, narrow space between rows ofseats in an aircraft, cinema, or church
amendment: a change or changes made to the words of a text
appear/arise: to start to be seen or to be present
appearance: an occasion when someone appears in public
to apply: to request something, usually officially, especially in writing or by sending in a form
to appreciate/value: to recognize how good someone or something is and to value him, her, or it
baggy: hanging loosely because of being too big or having been stretched
be reluctant: not willing to do something and therefore slow to do it
to betray: to not be loyal to your country or a person, often by doing something harmful such as helping their enemies
betrayal: an act of betraying someone or something, or the fact of someone or something being betrayed
borrow: to get or receive something from someone with the intention of giving it back after a period of time
breadwinner/breadmaker: the member of a family who earns themoney that the family needs
coincide: to happen at or near the same time, to be the same or similar
compare: to examine or look for the difference between two or more things
cope with: to deal successfully with a difficult situation
correction: a change made to something in order to correct or improve it, or theaction of making such a change
customer: a person who buys goods or aservice
disadvatages: a condition or situation that causesproblems, especially one that causes something or someone to be less successful than other things or people
doubt/hesitate: (a feeling of) not being certain about something, especially about how good or true it is
drawbacks: a disadvantage or the negative partof a situation
enrich: to improve the quality of something by adding something else
to exploit: to use something in a way that helps you
failure: the fact of someone or something not succeeding
fiction: the type of book or story that is written about imaginary characters andevents and not based on real peopleand facts
force: physical, especially violent, strength, or power
fridge: a piece of kitchen equipment that uses electricity to preserve food at acold temperature
get rid of: to not now have an unwanted orunpleasant task, object, or person
grateful: showing or expressing thanks,especially to another person
hills/slopes: an area of land that is higher than the surrounding land
hospitable: friendly and welcoming to guestsand visitors
improvement: an occasion when something gets better or when you make it better
injection: the act of putting a liquid, especiallya drug, into a person's body using aneedle and a syringe (= small tube)
injuries: physical harm or damage to someone's body caused by an accidentor an attack
inspiration: someone or something that gives you ideas for doing something
insurance: an agreement in which you pay acompany money and they pay yourcosts if you have an accident, injury, etc.
interrupt: to stop a person fromspeaking for a short period by something you say or do
invite: to ask or request someone to go to an event
irradiate: to treat with light or other types ofradiation
lack: the fact that something is notavailable or that there is not enough of it
landmarks/sights: a building or place that is easily recognized, especially one that you can use to judge where you are
lend: to give something to someone for a short period of time, expecting it to be given back
mature: Mature people behave like adults in a way that shows they are welldeveloped emotionally
mother tongue: the first language that you learn when you are a baby, rather than alanguage learned at school or as anadult
mustard: a thick yellow or brown sauce that tastes spicy and is eaten cold in smallamounts, especially with meat
notice: to see or become conscious of something or someone
ordeal: a very unpleasant and painful or difficult experience
otherwise: used after an order or suggestion to show what the result will be if you do not follow that order or suggestion
our guide: a book that gives you the most important information about a particular subject
patient: a person who is receiving medicalcare, or who is cared for by a particular doctor or dentist when necessary
pattern: a particular way in which something is done, is organized, orhappens
promote: to encourage people to like, buy, use, do, or support something
recipe: a set of instructions telling you how to prepare and cook food, including alist of what food is needed for this
rely on/hope for: to depend on or trust someone or something
remind: to make someone think of something they have forgotten or might have forgotten
reveal: to make known or show something that is surprising or that was previously secret
monotony: a situation in which something stays the same and is therefore boring
appliances: a device, machine, or piece of equipment, especially an electrical one that is used in the house, such as acooker or washing machine
brick: a rectangular block of hard material used for building walls andhouses
french windows: a pair of glass doors, usually openingfrom the back of a house into its garden
sequences: a series of related things orevents, or the order in which they follow each other
semi-detached house: A house that is semi-detached is one that is joined to another similar house on only one side
terraced: terrace built as or belonging to arow of often small houses join ed together along their side walls
cottage: a small house, usually in the countryside
bungalo: a house that usually has only onestorey (= level), sometimes with asmaller upper storey set in the roof andwindows that come out from the roof
managed: to succeed in doing or dealing with something, especially something difficult
persuaded: to make someone do or believe something by giving them a goodreason to do it or by talking to thatperson and making them believe it
compulsory: If something is compulsory, you must do it because of a rule or law
environmentally: relating to the environmentin which people, animals, and plants live
amount: a collection or mass, especially of something that cannot be counted
reduce: to become or to make something become smaller in size, amount, degree, importance, etc.
gherkin: pickle a small typeof cucumber (= a long, thin, greenvegetable) that is often pickled (=preserved in vinegar)
spire: a tall, pointed structure on top of abuilding, especially on top of a churchtower
presence: the fact that someone or something is in a place
upset: to make someone worried, unhappy, or angry
sharpen: to make something sharp or sharper
pay attention to: to watch, listen to, or think about something carefully
chapel: a room that is part of a largerbuilding and is used for Christianworship
sin: the offence of breaking, or the breaking of, a religious or moral law
mortage: an agreement that allows you to borrowmoney from a bank or similarorganization, especially in order to buya house, or the amount of money itself
loan: an amount of money that isborrowed, often from a bank, and has to be paid back, usually together with anextra amount of money that you have topay as a charge for borrowing
inconvenience: a state or an example of problemsor trouble, often causing a delay or lossof comfort
efficiency: the good use of time and energy in a way that does not waste any
consumers: a person who buys goods orservices for their own use
streamlining: to shape something so that it can moveas effectively and quickly as possible through a liquid or gas
foil: a very thin sheet of metal, especiallyused to wrap food in to keep it fresh
variety: the characteristic of oftenchanging and being different
throwaway: made to be destroyed after use
destruction: the act of destroying something, or the fact of being destroyed
wind-up: to find yourself in anunexpected and usuallyunpleasant situation, especiallyas a result of what you do
decided: certain, obvious, or easy to notice
be excited: to make someone have strong feelings of happiness and enthusiasm
oven: the part of a cooker with a door, used to bake or roast food
artificial: made by people, often as a copy of something natural
create impression: made an idea or opinion of what something or someone is like
wean oneself: to cause a baby or young animal to stop feeding on its mother's milk and to starteating other food, especially solid food, instead
roll: to make a continuous, repeated,deep sound
akes: a sweet food made with amixture of flour, eggs, fat, and sugar
accomplice: a person who helps someone else to commit a crime or to do something morally wrong
get involved: to do things and be part of an activity or event
litter: small pieces of rubbish that have been left lying on the ground inpublic places
demand: to ask for something forcefully, in a way that shows that you do not expectto be refused
supply: to provide something that is wanted or needed, often in large quantities and over a long period of time
hint: something that you say or do that shows what you think or want, usually in a way that is not direct
roots: family origins, or the particular place you come from and the experiences you have had living there
legislation: a law or set of laws suggested by agovernment and made official by aparliament
labourer: a person who does unskilled physical work, especially outside
boundary: a real or imagined line that marksthe edge or limit of something
allow: to give permission for someone to do something, or to not prevent something from happening
vegetation: plants in general, or plants that arefound in a particular area
fields: an area of land, used for growing crops or keeping animals, usually surrounded by a fence
flooding: a situation in which an area is coveredwith water, especially from rain
coal: a hard, black substance that is dugfrom the earth in pieces, and can beburned to produce heat or power, or asingle piece of this
awareness: knowledge that something exists, or understanding of a situation or subject at the present time based on information or experience
logging companies: the company of cutting down trees inorder to use their wood
avalanche: a large amount of ice, snow, and rockfalling quickly down the side of amountain
manage: to succeed in doing or dealing with something, especially something difficult
certain/particular: special, or this and not any other
equally: fairly and in the same way
opportunity: an occasion or situation that makes it possible to do something that you want to do or have to do, or the possibility of doing something
admire: to find someone or something attractive and pleasant to look at
enroll: to put yourself or someone else on anofficial list for an activity or for membership in a group, or to accept someone in such a list
request: the act of politely or officially asking for something
a burden: a heavy load that you carry
due: expected to happen, arrive, etc. at a particular time
into: to the inside or middle of a place, container, area, etc.
appreciation: he act of recognizing or understanding that something is valuable, important, or as described
hurricane: a violent wind that has a circular movement, especially in the West Atlantic Ocean
drought: a long period when there is little or no rain
earthquake: a sudden violent movement of the earth's surface, sometimes causing great damage
tidal wave: an extremely large wave caused by movement of the earth under the sea, often caused by anearthquake (= a shaking of the earth)
cause: the reason why something, especially something bad, happens
burst: to break open or apart suddenly, or to make something do this
survivor: a person who continues to live, despite nearly dying
stranded: unable to leave somewhere because of a problem such as not having any transport or money
starvation: the state of having no food for a long period, often causing death
refugee: a person who has escaped from their owncountry for political, religious, or economicreasons or because of a war
contaminated: to make something less pure or make it poisonous
supplies: food and other ordinary goods needed by people every day
famine: a situation in which there is not enough foodfor a great number of people, causing illness anddeath, or a particular period when this happens
suburb: an area on the edge of a large town or citywhere people who work in the town or city oftenlive
precinct: a part of a city or a town in which vehiclesare not allowed, used for a special purpose, such as shopping
lane: a narrow road in the countryside or in a town
gambling: the activity of betting money, for example in agame or on a horse race
Affiliation: to cause a group to become part of or form a close relationship with another, usuallylarger, group, or organization
cosmopolitan: containing or having experience of people and things from many different parts of the world
efficient: working or operating quickly and effectively in an organized way
congestion: Congested roads and towns have too much trafficand movement is made difficult.
appeal: a request to the public for money,information, or help
threshold: the floor of an entrance to a building or room
diligent: careful and using a lot of effort
convince: to persuade someone or make someone certain
tile: a thin, usually square or rectangular piece of bakedclay, plastic, etc. used for covering roofs, floors ,walls, etc.
greet: to welcome someone with particular words or a particular action, or to react to something in the stated way
observe: to watch carefully the way somethinghappens or the way someone does something,especially in order to learn more about it
crops: (the total amount collected of) a plant such as a grain, fruit, or vegetable grown in largeamounts
magnificent: very good, beautiful, or deserving to beadmired
dig: to break up and move soil using a tool, amachine, or your hands
well: in a good way, to a high or satisfactorystandard
allocate: to give something to someone as their share of a total amount, to use in a particular way
pine tree: anevergreen tree (= one that neverloses its leaves) that grows incooler areas of the world
extinguish: to stop a fire or a light burning
perceive: to come to an opinion about something, or have a belief about something
syringe: a hollow, cylinder-shapedpiece of equipment used for sucking liquid out of something or pushing liquid into something, especially one with aneedle that can be put under the skin and used toinject drugs, remove small amounts of blood, etc.
penalty: a punishment, or the usual punishment, for doing something that is against a law
fur: the thick hair that covers the bodies of some animals, or the hair-covered skin(s) of animals, removed from their bodies
conscientious: putting a lot of effort into your work
further: to a greaterdistance or degree, or at a moreadvanced level
dull: not interesting or exciting in any way
scheme: an organized plan for doing something, especially something dishonest or illegal that will bring a good result for you
